subsections.title: Net-zero goal and strategy
text: Somalia does not have a net-zero goal or strategy.

subsections.title: Nationally Determined Contributions (NDC)
text: Somalia has an Absolute Target nationally determined contribution as its official plan to cut emissions under the Paris Agreement. The country has committed to reduce and avoid emissions 30% by 2030 compared to a Business as Usual scenario. There are no specific sectors that are targeted.  Somalia has yet to submit a long-term strategy under the Paris Agreement.

subsections.title: Fossil fuel phase-out policy
text: Somalia does not have a fossil fuel phase-out policy.

subsections.title: Power policy
text: Somalia’s on-grid market has very little investment opportunities. There are no PPA award methods.

subsections.title: Power prices and costs
text: Power prices in Somalia are fairly high because most of the country is powered by privately owned diesel generators. There are no subsidies for fossil fuels, but there are taxes. However, tax evasion is common because citizens believe that their payments are diverted from making public improvements. The insurgent group Al-Shabaab also levies taxes, so citizens are reluctant to pay taxes twice.

subsections.title: Power market
text: Somalia’s energy sector was destroyed following the collapse of the central government in 1991. Residents were forced to depend on privately owned diesel generators while many were left in the dark. At this time, more than seven electricity companies operate in the country – all owned by private individuals. Due to this, the sector is not very concentrated, but there are no plans to decarbonize it. There is very little renewable capacity on the grid; most renewables have arrived via off-grid solar methods.
The off-grid sector is more active in Somalia. The country has an active pay-as-you-go (PAYG) sector. However, this is not widely integrated with solar home systems.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: Somalia is a very difficult country to do business in due to its multiple risk factors. Utility debt is very high and there is an absence of legal or regulatory policy. Electrification rates are still low at 35% nationally, with 66% in urban areas and 11% in rural areas. Somalia does not have any rural electrification programs.

subsections.title: EV market
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: EV policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the EV market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: There is not an active market.

subsections.title: Buildings market
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heat market remains at an early stage. There is international support for sustainable building development in the form of grants.

subsections.title: Buildings policy
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector and the low-carbon heat market remains at an early stage.

subsections.title: Doing business and barriers
text: The government has yet to implement any substantive policy support in this sector.
